Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Story:
My phone buzzed in my pocket just as I was sitting beside my sister, who was curled up on the couch, tears streaming down her face. She’d just gotten the call about Dad’s diagnosis, and I could feel her pain as if it were my own. I knew she needed me—needed someone to hold her, to listen, to just be there. That’s what we always promised each other: no matter what, we’d be there in the hardest moments.

But then my phone rang again, this time with a frantic call from my best friend, Sam. His voice shook as he told me his car had broken down on the highway, miles from home, and he was scared. He needed me to come get him right away. I could hear the cars rushing past him, the fear in his voice. He’d always been there for me, and I knew he was counting on me now.

I looked at my sister, her eyes red and pleading, and then at my phone, Sam’s name still glowing on the screen. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be in two places at once, torn between the people who needed me most.
